captions.text:
Octopath is sadly not what Chris Eubank calls
his favourite kind of marine life, it just
means eight paths.

Octopath traveler is a game about going through
the stories - or travelling the paths, if
you will - of eight characters.

Might seem a bit on the nose as titles go,
but then it is a Japanese game, probably sounds
cooler in a foreign language.

&quot;Yes, it actually literally means &#39;eight paths&#39;
in English.&quot;

&quot;Gosh, you&#39;re so clever and worldly, Square
Enix-san.&quot;

It&#39;s like how any food sounds classier if
you give it a French name.

&quot;Merde de chien a le gravier&quot; probably sounds
a lot more palatable than &quot;dog turds in gravel.&quot;

Anyway, Octopath Graveller is a JRPG, but
don&#39;t hold that against it because it&#39;s deliberately

trying to evoke an older era of JRPGs when
they were more tolerable, and weren&#39;t all

overdesigned bogwash and prolonged fashion
parades on the planet of melodramatic emotionally
stunted shitheads.

Actually thinking about it that&#39;s been less
the case with JRPGs lately, possibly because

we haven&#39;t had a new Final Fantasy in a while
and the last one we did have was about people
going around relatively soberly dressed.

But while we&#39;re on the subject it&#39;s games
like Final Fantasy 6 that Octuplet Unraveller
is most trying to ape.

The seminal 16-bit Final Fantasy that hit
the perfect sweet spot between the series

beginning to indulge more complex plots in
less standard fantasy settings, and everything

turning into convoluted magitechno visual
diarrhoea and whatever the fuck was going
on with Final Fantasy X.

At least everything was visually consistent
in 2D times - nice readable tile-based environments

and every character a super deformed bighead
lad with exactly the same face so they all
look like chronically overdressed Lemmings.

That&#39;s the visual style Octopus Raddler is
going for, although the little 2D character

sprites are all running around fully 3D environments
with pixelly 16-bit textures stretched over

them, all rendered in accordance with graphical
standards of the modern age, meaning everything

is lit like an overexposed photo and slighty
brown.

So, here comes my challenge, viewers - in
order to gauge the effectiveness of the game&#39;s

story I&#39;m now going to attempt to list all
eight characters and their story arcs from
memory alone.

There&#39;s Tressa, an underage girl who vows
with the lofty ambition of youth to dedicate

her life to becoming a really good travelling
merchant, this being a more innocent time
before child protection services.

Then there&#39;s Cyrus, a teacher who gets fired
because of some Mean Girls drama and goes
looking for an overdue library book or something.
Um.

Oh yeah, Primrose, she&#39;s a stripper assassin
who shows her commitment to revenge by refusing
to put trousers on regardless of the weather.

Er... this might be easier if I try to remember
their classes rather than their personalities.

So there&#39;s standard warrior man with sword,
who is seeking justice on the man who robbed

him of honour because aren&#39;t they fucking
always.

The thief, Therion, I remember his name because
it contains most of the letters of &#39;thief&#39;,

and his story involves having to steal some
things because if you&#39;ve only got one thing
going for you might as well own it, I say.

Priest, yep, got one of them, some blonde
lady going on a pilgrimage because the lady

who was supposed to do it called in sick or
something.
How many&#39;s that?
Six.
Shit.

Oh yeah, there&#39;s the hunter lady looking for
her missing master who comes from the village

where everyone talks like they got really
drunk at a renaissance faire and decided they
were just gonna have fun with it.
Lastly, apothecary lad.

Their friend gets poisoned, they cure the
poison, then they decide to travel the world
because the format demands it.
Well, I suppose we can&#39;t all be stripper assassins.
Not all stories are created equal.

So it&#39;s weird that while you can freely swap
out three members of your four-man party,

whoever you picked first leads the party permanently,
so don&#39;t pick apothecary lad first as you&#39;ll

be stuck with him like a piece of toilet paper
trailing from your shoe.

And what I find iffy about the whole presentation
is that I rarely get a sense that my rag-tag

bunch of anime misfits are actually interacting
with each other.

For the first part of the game you tour all
the home villages randomly touching people

until one goes &quot;Hello, random group of strangers,
I&#39;m about to embark on a very personal quest

that will define the rest of my life, why
not tag along?&quot;

and that&#39;s your new party member, smilingly
joining up with a group of what might be cannibalistic
serial tax dodgers for all they know.

Accepting that they&#39;re going to have to mutely
witness the personal bullshit of seven complete

strangers before they come back around to
sorting out whatever put a hair up their own
arse.

It&#39;s particularly jarring with characters
like Primrose doing the &quot;I am dishonored and

alone and have nothing left in this world
but my quest for violent bloody revenge&quot; bit,

never acknowledging the seven colourful dudes
at varying stages of adolescence with whom
she shares a sleeping bag every night.

It&#39;s only right at the end of the game that
any connection between the eight stories is
established.

Before that, it&#39;s eight separate stories,
rather than a story about eight people.

Every time you go through a new chapter of
one party member&#39;s story everyone else just

disappears up their butthole for the duration
of the cutscene.

Sometimes after a cutscene a little button
prompt comes up and you can teleport the relevant

character and one other party member to the
interaction dimension where they discuss what
just happened.

But I don&#39;t see why they couldn&#39;t have worked
that into the scene, made it look like some

actual organic relationship building was going
on, not just a spot of post-match commentary
like Statler and fuckin&#39; Waldorf.

The structure of Octagon Waffler&#39;s gameplay
meanwhile is kinda formulaic.

Every chapter goes through the same motions
- you pursue whoever villain du episode is

through a little maze of random combat encounters,
confront them at the end, they turn into twenty

foot realistically drawn version of themselves
and you fight them for absolutely bloody ages.

As for the combat it&#39;s fine, I guess, you
take it in turns to twat each other which
is to my mind essential for turn-based combat.

There&#39;s also this whole system based around
figuring out enemy weaknesses to knock out

their defenses, and saving up our glowing
power testicles so we can scrunch them all

up at once to do an extra damaging attack,
but I think Square-Enix are indulging the
modern JRPG tendency to overthink things.

I mean, I liked how the combat in Final Fantasy
6 was straightforward and didn&#39;t get in the

way much - enemies attack, twat twat twat,
enemies go away, the universe uncrosses its
legs.

Here, even the random battles drag on a bit,
and not the fun kind of dragon.

All in all, I would classify Otacon Breviller
as a timekiller.

It doesn&#39;t trouble my story liking brain or
tickle my gameplay gonads much, and too much

of it is rampant cliche and grind, which is
funnily enough the name of my usual law firm.

After the first round of story chapters I
was about six below the recommended level
for the next one and thus did things get grindy.

Once I&#39;d fucking found somewhere to grind,
of course, considering the game map refuses

to tell you what level each area is suitable
for.

In retrospect maybe I shouldn&#39;t have equipped
that passive perk Cyrus had that reduced the
number of random encounters.

But it was his only perk at the time and it
took ages to learn so what was I supposed
to do, NOT equip it?

That&#39;s like giving me a long cylindrical object
and telling me not to stick it up me dog&#39;s
bum.
